description:
Love this place! I've literally never ordered anything on the menu I didn't love. I highly recommend the lunch special with chow fun. 

The staff is really friendly and the decor inside is really unique and cool too. A treasure in the neighborhood!
author: Mandy G.

description:
People with Diabetes watch out. This place has gotten worse. The sauce has gotten extra sweet. Every dish tasted like you're eating tablespoons of sugar. The mapao tofu dish was so sweet. When I complained they said it's prob the bean sauce but every mapao tofu lover knows that do ban jiang is salty and definitely not sweet

No Chinese people dine here so i guess that's a sign. This will be my last time here
author: Sam S.

description:
FINALLY! I've found my Chinese restaurant in Pac Heights! 

I've looked for a Chinese spot in Pac Heights since moving to the neighborhood and I've never had any luck until last week when I tried Eliza's. I ordered take-out on a weeknight - it was quick and they got my food/had me pay swiftly upon arriving. The Beef and Broccoli was delicious and well-portioned. I also liked the potstickers. I will definitely be returning to Eliza's in the future to try more delicious food!
author: Katie C.

description:
It's a pity how this place has changed over the years.  The portions are so small it's hard to enjoy because 2 bites and it's finished
The size has become so ridiculous compared to other places.
author: Danitza A.

description: There were 30 of us. I was soooooo worried they wouldn't take us but they did. They took our huge party and the food was great! All my family was fed and we all had a good time! Thank you very much for your service! We will be back!!!
author: Amparo R.

description: If you are a 6 oz. gerbal, then the portions here may fill you up. If you're a normal human, the portions are a joke. You can eat 6 dollars worth of food in one bite. And its 12 dollar meal. Seriously, I dont know how this place stays in business... food was decent, but not any better than the 9000 other Chinese food places that serve actual meals and not over priced snacks.
author: McGee J.

description: Really disappointed by the small portion sizes. Wish I had listened to the other reviews. They charge more than other Chinese restaurants in the area, but the portion sizes are made for toddlers. Toddlers who aren't hungry at that! This is the first time in my life I received a to-go box that was 3/4 empty. Beware!
author: Dani B.

description: My favorite Chinese on the north end of SF. Only go for take out, have not dined in. Their Mongolian beed is the best in the city!
author: Michael B.

description:
NOT FAMILY FRIENDLY. 

Do not bring your kids here. They are rude to them and have no desire to have families with small children. 

We went at 5pm and the place was empty!!

We have been eating here for 15 years and will no longer support them. They gave us tiny portions and added gratuity to the bill. Then they asked us not to come back until the kids were older.
author: Tammy N.

description:
This art deco meets zen garden restaurant is NOT your typical hole-in-the wall takeout spot. 

It's so clean, fast, and affordable serving some of the most delicious Hunan and Mandarin food with beautiful presentation. 

Located in a residential part of Lower Pac Heights makes prices and parking better. Also, the staff is fast and efficient. 

Their lunch deals are amazing- you get soup, rice, choice of protein, and rice. I rarely say this, but after having tried 75% of their menu, I can trust that anything you order will be high quality deliciousness. This is what I would usually order for two people:

Apps: Pot Stickers
Soup: Sweet & Sour
Main: Hunan Fish, Mango Beef, Snow Peas Beef, Crab Chow Fun, and/or Eliza's Beef, Chicken & Pork Fried Rice

Wine and Beer only.
author: Mitzi G.

description: A nice solid favorite lunch location. A nice menu with several choices, great flavor, and quick service, friendly service. I tend to go for the Mongolian Lamb, or the Chow Fun! But there are several other yummy options on the menu. I've tried a good number of options on the menu, but still have a ways to go! Looking forward to it!
author: Dezi S.

description:
I work a block away and came here for lunch to eat inside.

They don't give change back after your meal, don't expect it. They keep it as tip.

Anyway, their lunch menu is pretty affordable. I tried their sweet and sour pork. Sadly, it tasted too American for me. Not authentic. I'm thinking I may try another dish to give them another chance, but it highly unlikely I will.
author: Lynn C.

description:
I really enjoyed my experience at Eliza's. Mainly because if the food! The decor and service were fine, nothing special, nothing bad. But the food was great. First of all, get the pot stickers. Best I've ever had. A little crunch on one side from being cooked, but not overly crunchy, perfect IMO. I got the Kung Pao Chicken. It was that perfect blend of spicy, but not so spicy you can't enjoy it. The veggies were cooked perfectly. My wife got a dish with spicy chicken and basil. She had never had basil and tomatoes with an Asian dish and thought it was to die for. 

I thought the prices were fair considering the area. I'm from Ohio, and all the prices is Cali are higher, but so didn't feel the same way about Eliza's.
author: Adam R.

description: Somewhat better than average Americanized Chinese food but not worth the extra price.Service was not friendly at all
author: Mark P.

description: Went here just now and nobody would seat me. There were open seats. There was staff that saw me. I've been a customer here more than 15 years. Not cool. Eventually I just walked out. We'll see if I ever walk back in.
author: Michael K.

description: My husband and I go here just for the hot and sour soup. We always get to go because the inside has kind of a weird vibe, hence the 4 stars.
author: Christa N.

description: Food is good, lunch equals small portions however. So if yer hungry, ask for other options cause they ain't pushing them. My pal & I had an entree each, split another & we were still hungry.
author: Henry K.

description:
Very good quality, but you pay slightly more. Everything was very fresh tasting.

Eat here if you want Chinese food but with better attention to quality and freshness.

Hot and sour vegetarian version: highly recommend.

Baby bok choy with garlic: highly recommend.

Service: real good.

Keep it up Ellliiiiiizzaaaaaa!!!!
author: Auza A.

description:
Been going here for a few years and the service is getting better! My go to lunch place in lower pac heights.  Excellent lunch special deals, super tasty, great ambience, and they get you in and out in about 40 mins.  haven't tried dinner yet.  

Best item on the menu; sautéed string beans!

So so item; most shrimp dishes.
author: Dj S.

description: It's unfortunate when the restaurant you and your family have been coming to for 12 years tries to rip you off. I eat here once a week and this is the first time they have tried to make me pay for nothing. I ordered potstickers and then was told i would have to pay an extra 3.50 for no reason. Greedy. Very unfortunate.
author: Megan M.

description:
I've probably been here/ordered out from Eliza's a dozen times.  For better or for worse, we always get the same few dishes.  Potstickers, chow mein, lemon chicken, and sweet & sour pork.  It's all incredible and very consistent.  Prices are fair.

It's a great place to bring out of town guests on a budget, especially pickier eaters who don't want to go too exploratory with all of the unique SF places.

The interior is neatly decorated and the owners/staff have been the same for years.  In my opinion, it's the perfect family run local Chinese place to have in your neighborhood.

This seems to be the only place of its kind in a couple mile radius, so props to you Eliza's!  Looking forward to coming back again and again with family and friends.
author: Meaghan H.

description:
Tired and starving from driving around the city I looked up Chinese food for something quick and tasty. I ordered Eliza's chowmein for pickup and we were parked just up the street so my wife ran down and grabbed it for us. 

This was some of the best tasting Chinese food I have had in a long time! We slurped it down with ease while our children slept in the back of the car. 
There was thinly sliced lotus root included which was a very nice touch. It had three different kinds of meat and an amazing sauce. There was a plethora of fresh veggies included as well. I will definitely be back next time we are in the city.
author: Andrew R.

description: On the pricier side for Chinese food, but then again, it is in Pacific Heights. The food itself had good flavor and good quality. The decor is modern and unique. Repeater.
author: Will H.

description: This is quite possibly the best Chinese restaurant in the city. I come regularly for lunch and have never had a bad experience. The staff is attentive, the food is delicious, and the price is right. Looking forward to my next visit.
author: Xavier C.

description:
Enjoyed the elegant (elegantish?) dining room and the professional service, but was disappointed by the quality and quantity of the food.  Helps to explain why the awards seemed to end more than a decade ok.

Nothing wrong with trying to create a fine dining experience with Chinese food, but frankly, we would have preferred cheap shopping mall Chinese food over this. 

Sorry to post a negative review, but it's how we felt.
author: Jane D.

description: Yummy Chinese Food. If you desire authentic varieties of Chinese food that are well seasoned, spices, and prepared, then you must go to Eliza's. Also, Eliza's May have a few scowling waitresses, but that should not let you effect your experience. One more thing, the decorations are mostly glass and ceramics and scrolls that are authentic!
author: Caleb L.

description:
Sigh.

I don't want to hoof it to the Richmond for amazing Chinese chow. So, we ended up at pricey Eliza's. While the slightly modern setting is lovely, the dishes elegantly presented, the prices are so very Pacific Heights. Entree prices hover around $10 and up. 

We liked our string beans with bean curd as well as the chicken stir fry with Chinese broccoli. The rice is perfectly fluffed and free refills on black tea was appreciated. The smart locals obviously come here for lunch, since they have their cheap, cheap $6.95 lunch deals.
author: Janice C.

description:
As a mostly western Chinese restaurant, the food is just above average and overpriced. The Hunan beef and dumplings in particular are the star dishes if you decide to give this mainstay a try. 

I have decided to give Eliza's 1 star because all the Hunan beef and dumplings in the world cannot forgive the consistent appalling customer service. It almost feels like you are an inconvenience! Below I will give you two examples of the customer service I have received over the years:

1. Using the company Doordash, I ordered Eliza fried rice, Eliza chow mein, sweet and sour chicken and Hunan beef. Unfortunately, I only received two correct items; I contacted Eliza first and the woman I spoke to tried to blame me for their mistake! To add insult, she also tried to make out that the incorrect items I had received were the correct items. I'm pretty sure deep fried beef cannot pass off as fried rice! In the end, the woman told me there was nothing she could do and to contact the delivery company. No apology, not even a goodbye. I then proceeded to contact Doordash who credited my account with the price of the missing items. 

2. I order over $200 of food over the telephone and as it's a Friday night I call an hour in advance of the intended pickup time. Walking into the restaurant, I queue patiently behind 3 individuals waiting to either pick up their order or make an order; the front of house server was walking to and from the kitchen at a zombie pace; 10 minutes later it's my turn and I'm told that my order is nearly ready and to take a seat. Another 10 minutes elapse and during my 20 minute wait, I can't help but notice that only a handful of tables actually have food on their table. Queue alarm bells. Reaching the 25 minute mark, I try to get the attention of a member of staff to ask how much longer my order will be but they are all blatantly ignoring me! I give up because the people that were in front of me when I arrived are also trying to get a servers' attention. Eventually, a full 30 minutes since arriving at the restaurant, the front of house server appears with my food. No apology and no goodbye!

I should also point out that I would not recommend going to this restaurant if there are more than 4 in your group as food can take considerably longer; it's also not the most child friendly!
author: Simon Y.

description: Absolutely the BEST Chinese restaurant in all of SF!!!  Especially yummy is the Shanghai Chicken, Lemon Shrimp and Mu Shu Pork. But pretty much everything is delicious. It's not at all like the average Chinese food you're used to. Way way better.
author: Steve W.

description: I would not bother to come here again. I have been here a few times in the past, and the food has been acceptable--perhaps even better than some Chinese restaurants. However, the chicken in my dish tonight was almost imperceptible, and the pieces were small and gristly. For the price, I expect much better quality. Even Panda Express has better chicken--and this is a bit of a sad statement. Do yourself a favor and forego this dinner stop.
author: Shadi G.

description:
A childhood favorite that had been serving quality, delicious and healthy Chinese food for years. So glad they're still open and thriving. Keep it up, Eliza's! 

My go tos:

Hoisin green beans
Wok tossed broccoli
Chow mein
Eliza's chicken 
Green onion pancake
author: Sarah L.

description: We had...the potstickers, princess prawns, sizzling rice soup, eggplant in a spicy sauce, and green beans with tofu.  The prawns were like candy, the veggies cooked just right.  Don't miss out on the sizzling soup - man did that go down easy! We enjoyed each and every dish - and each one of us had a different favorite.  We were greeted warmly, and seated well.  Food was served up hot, fast and fresh.  Amazingly efficient - and all of it well done.  The atmosphere is a trip - a feast for the eyes.  Immerse in the art - and take the time to see the detail.  It's whimsical, fun and tastefully done.  Back to the food - smelled and tasted heavenly.  I understand why this is my niece's all time favorite.  You'd miss out if you don't try it.  Kept the phone in the bag - so let your imagination create pictures of the food - excellent!
author: Joenne M.

description: So... Eliza's used to be a solid neighborhood place to pick up Chinese food. But the last couple times the ingredients of the dishes have gotten flimsy.  The quality and flavors of the cooking are still good. What I mean is that they're skimping on ingredients, being cheap.  I ordered the cashew chicken and it was all broccoli and hardly any chicken or cashews.  It's supposed to be "cashew chicken" not "Broccoli with a touch of chicken and cashew."  Sadly, I can not recommend them anymore :(
author: F S.

description: I've only had two entree dishes here but they were both amazing! Went here for lunch with my guy and ordered garlic shrimp and lemon shrimp with spring rolls. The lunch entree came with an egg and tomatoe soup as well. Everything was delicious, seasoned well, flavorful, and cooked just right. I live across town but the food was so good I'd make the trip!
author: Tameika E.

description: Eliza's is great if you are in the neighborhood. I like the Buddha's delight(vegetarian) and the Spicy chicken(orange chicken). All the food I've tried has been good. The service is fast and they are nice. I normally order takeout, but it would be nice to sit down too. There is never much of a wait.
author: Lauren A.

description: This place is no longer the old Eliza's on Potrero Hills, which was good.  Burnt green beans, greasy chicken, thick black sauce-- nothing was edible.
author: Apple M.

description:
This Chinese eatery in PacHeights is somewhat neglected on Yelp - probably because it's located in a very residential area between Divis and Richmond. Nothing else there other than apartment buildings.

Surprisingly packed at dinner time on a Friday night, Eliza's has an inviting yet a bit outdated interior - large colored glass walls, a small bar, and around 15 tables. Our party got seated quickly and glanced at the menu. The food seems to be tailored to the neighborhood - Chinese food for the Western taste, which is not necessarily a bad thing, if done right. The BROCCOLI BEEF w/ WHITE RICE ($12) was tasty and quite alright, the portion size however pretty small. I tried the HONEY WALNUT SHRIMP w/ WHITE RICE ($12) which was satisfying both in plate size and flavor. 

I'll go back there to try some more from their menu but so far it has been an okay experience.
author: Sebastian F.

description: Had my first date with my current spouse at Eliza's when they had a location on Potrero Hill. Sixteen years later the food is still as good as ever and a wonderful reminder of that evening.
author: James B.

description:
I came here this evening after a long absence.  At least ten years.  Don't know why, because the food was and still is very good. The Basil Chicken, and Eggplant and Prawns were delicious as well as the appetizer sampler.  Love the egg rolls and pot stickers.  Everything arrived hot and each dish was perfectly seasoned.  Nice flavors and presentation.  

Eliza has been around a long time.  They started out in the Civic Center / Hayes Valley area and was a great lunch spot.  There is a reason they've been around for awhile.
author: Donna P.

description: Good food, the management are jerks.  Bad people who don't treat their customers with respect or courtesy.
author: Sarah A.

description: The food is delicious. Tasty, fresh and very good. Price is reasonable and the service is fast. Definitely recommended. Checkout the lunch menus
author: Ahmad N.

description: I'm obsessed with their szechuan eggplant and prawns! This place is one of my favorite places to get Chinese food in SF. I've eaten in the restaurant only once - mostly go for the take-out option, which seems to be the go to for many locals. Highly recommend this spot.
author: Ashley H.

description: Excellent. Simply excellent. I think I've been over 20 times since I first found it in 2014. My family from San Jose even makes the trip up to sf about once a month for dinner here. We've tried almost everything on the menu and each is phenomenal. ESP the Peking Duck!!!
author: Naseem K.

description:
The real thrill is how incredibly unfriendly and grumpy everyone is who works there. The faster they serve you the faster they think they can go home!
And if you have any interest in savoring a meal, be prepared for a deluge of all that you ordered as fast as it can be produced. The check will come just as fast and you will wonder what just happened!
Under no circumstance, ask for anything like water, rice,  or chili oil after the meal is served.
Food is pretty good but classic westernized style of hong kong food.
author: Russell N.

description: I have been a customer of Eliza's for over ten years and they are my favorite Chinese place in sf.  Don't always expect the warmest service but be prepared for some good food.
author: Lindsey G.

description: The WonTon soup is really good but not really worth the rudeness of the staff.
author: Pamela T.

description: My fav chinese spot in SF. Crab rangoon and mango beef are to die for. Can't beat the lunch deal either!
author: Lily L.

description: I've given this place several chances for redemption since its close to where I work and I like to support small businesses, but.... in my book, this place is always a dissapontment. Today I ordered the "sesame chicken", which was basically chicken in a black bean type sauce, with crushed black sesame and regular sesame seeds on top. 3/4 of the to go box was filled with shredded vegtables and hardley any chicken.  Never again will I come here.
author: Sara C.

description: Not the best Chinese food in town. Definitely not a big fan of the food there: not authentic and lack of taste. With so many good Chinese options in the town, definitely will not try this one
author: Jessica C.

description:
Food is very good

Staff is very rude and surly.

Contemptuous of their customers.

Not sure i would return.

Good customer service is important for 
A pleasant eating experience.
author: Ron M.

description: Rudest staff I have ever encountered. I am a delivery driver and they refused to print me a receipt for my customer so I could complete my order saying they already gave it to me. I will never eat here just based on the way the staff looked at me and spoke down to me
author: Brianna C.

description:
Just ok. I was really excited to try this place, but I was disappointed. The food here isn't authentic. It honestly doesn't even taste like Chinese food. For the chowmein, you mix the noodles with some kind of sauce that tastes like a microwaveable chowmein box you see at the grocery store. The quality isn't like a microwaveable dinner, but it has the same taste as one of those.

The interior is nice, but it has the feel of what contemporary meant in the 90s. I also tried a special duck dish. I love duck, but again, the flavor of the dish just didn't taste right. Americanized Chinese food. Don't get me wrong, I can like some non-authentic Chinese food like how I sometimes crave Chipotle over a taqueria (when it comes down to a specific taste you like, you just like it), but when it just tastes like a microwaveable take on Chinese food, no thanks. 

Service was good, but don't think I'd go back.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Ordered the lunch special Mango Beef that came with rice (white or brown) and a bowl of soup. It usually comes medium spicy but I asked them to make it mild. I was a bit disappointed when the dish came out because it was a smaller portion than I was used to getting at other Chinese restaurants for the same price ($7.45) but it was actually just the right amount of food that left me full but not food coma status. The beef slices were very thin but there was A LOT of mango so if you like mango, try this dish! 

Service was fine - they were very on top of collecting our plates when we finished eating. Plus we got in and out of there in less than 45 minutes! If you're on a time crunch/have a short lunch, definitely come here. Wouldn't recommend for large parties though, they don't have a lot of seating for big groups. 

The interior design is definitely an interesting combination of antiques and modern, clear furniture. Check out their bathroom too! It's like an aquarium in there - no actual fish tank though :(.
author: Amy Q.

description: Cancelled online order.  You have lost a customer.  If you can't manage your online partners, you do not deserve to be in business in SF. Period.
author: Christophe B.

description: Completely satisfied with our take out on Friday 5/26/17. Haven't been in a long time prefer to eat in because it is one of the prettiest. But we were tired so did take out. As I was perusing the menu on Yelp I was reading lousy reviews so I must disagree. Ours was very good. Hot and Sour soup- yes. And the Princess Prawns good as was the Hunan Beef, Eliza's Spicy Chicken and Eliza's Fried Rice. All Yummy.  Will be back.
author: Jewel S.

description: I love Elizas take on Chinese food. Absolutely love their sesame chicken, their Kung pow chicken, and their Mushu vegetable. They also have a great combination taster tray. Their dumplings are also spot on!
author: Paris S.

description:
By far my favorite Chinese food in the Bay Area. It's delicious, the potstickers are phenomenal and big, and the presentation of the dishes is delightful and whimsical. You will also find dishes and ingredients and flavor combinations that you can't find anywhere else in the city.

Highly recommend this place.

Favorites:
- Potstickers
- Mandarin Eggplant
- Eliza's Spicy Chicken
- Shanghai Chicken
- Hoisin String Beans
- Sunflower Beef

The staples are also good:
- Chow mein
- Mongolian Beef
- Chow Fun
author: Jesse H.

description:
Growing up in the area meant coming here for Eliza's amazing lunch special at least once a week! Especially because Eliza's hot and sour soup is THE best around! It's a large menu, so the usual a know their favorites. In my opinion, you can't go wrong with:

Sesame chicken
Eliza's spicy green beans
Mango chicken
Mongolian beef

Also, the decor is lovely and uniquely quirky. A great pac heights staple.
author: Talia B.

description: I love this place when it comes to Chinese  food. Their yellow curry and basil chicken are my all time favorites. I also love their soups.
author: Devan K.

description:
How is it possible I have never reviewed this place only 1.5 blocks away?

I kinda forget it is there, then when friends are in town and want a casual close-by dinner I often take them here, and they are blown away by the quality (Not NY'ers mind you, but from anywhere else).  

It truly is one of the best reasonably-priced Chinese restaurants in the city.  

Their lunch specials cannot be beat, cheap as hell (in the $6.50 range), and a ton of quality food with a choice of brown rice for no up-charge). Love the cashew chicken, and the black bean beef, but I have never been dissapointed with any other choices.

As far as dinner entrees, my fav is the mongolian beef and the Mu Shu pork, I only wish the portion of the Mongolian beef was bigger. Appetizer:  oooh those eliza cakes with the peanut dressing. If peking duck is a special (FRrday & Saturday) go ahead and splurge. yummy.

Only gripe is that the place needs a redesign, they don't deliver, and on Monday holidays you can't get the lunch specials (regular menu only).
author: Amy W.

description: Been going there since it opened with such a bang when you had to wait a long time in line. Decor was gorgeous, food beautiful and delicious. Servers rude as can be - cold like ice. Have not been there for a while now but went yesterday. Got there at 6:15 for dinner and no one else was in the place. We left at 7:30 and there was only one other table of 3 people. Well, the decor is still gorgeous, the food is not quite as good and the waitstaff still so rude. Ruder than ever. I had a question about a dish so signaled the one person on the floor. Sour faced as can be, she asked me what I wanted. I told her softly I just have a question. With one defiant hand on her hip and head cocked meanly to one side, she asked what it was. Well, I told her I did not want to holler all the way across the room so could she come over to our table. She refused. Said there was no one in the restaurant anyway so I could holler it out. Finally our waiter came over and answered the question. Meanwhile, is she wondering why there was no one in the place with nastiness like hers? I will not be going back.
author: Janet G.

description:
This is one of my favorite chinese restaurants in the area. 

Sit down is quiet and quaint...the decor is a bit cheesy Chinese restaurant, lol. Instead, i just love to order their food or take out, take it home, curl up on the couch with a friend, watch a movie and munch on all the Chinese goodness I ordered from this place. It's the best way to eat the stuff from here. 

My favorite is the pan fried noodles, so good! 

But I would have to say that everything my friends have ordered, or I have seen people order looks good and fresh. 

Definitely a must try. Make sure to grab a menu when you pick up your first order, so you have it handy for future take out orders. You will be back for more orders, I promise;)
author: Sonia A.

description: I always come to Eliza's when I'm in San Fran. They have the best Szechuan chicken in the city. And their Mongolian beef is to die for!
author: Adam P.

description: The food is pretty good but I just find the servers so rude every time and it's a real turnoff. Also my husband must be gluten free. for a health condition, and they are extremely unaccommodating and annoyed about it every time. If it wasn't right in my neighborhood I would look for another spot but for better or worse convenience will prevail!
author: Alison T.

description: I have been coming to this restaurant for 16 years and it has continually been the best chinese food. Amazing place.
author: Kristen J.

description:
We only have been here a couple times but each time it was delicious. 

Chow mien, sizzling rice soup and vegetable Kung pow was very tasty.
author: Derek S.

description:
Good God teach those people customer service. 

Food is ok. Place is clean bit customer service ruins it all.

Is it that hard to say THANK YOU!???
People choose your place to eat among thousands of others in this city. 

Waitress borough me chopsticks with such face as if I was asking to bring me her personal wallet. 

Come on!!! This is restaurant - at least be polite.
author: Marianna P.

description: I have had it with the 2 old grumpy owners of this place. Never a hello or a smile or glad to see you back. I just spent 52 bucks and asked for 4 more fortune cookies and was told not to press my luck. To heck with you, I'll never go back grumpy people.
author: dan H.

description: love, Love, LOVE Eliza's!!!! Been coming here for many years. Always good quality, fast service & de-lish!
author: P W.

description:
Watch out...food has gone down hill for awhile,
the bottom of the menu has an $11 minimum charge!!!! my 6 and 8 year Olds ate very little but still got the $22 charge....RUDE as well.
long time customer says, GOODBYE, never again!!
author: Mike H.

description:
Used to come here a lot for lunch, now I'm only around for dinner.

The lunch specials are great, very reasonable prices, including tea and a cup of soup of the day. 

I'm a huge fan of the Mongolian lamb, great flavor and well seasoned.  The included veggies compliment the meat very nicely and don't overtake the dish.  

Garlic chicken is great as well, but I've noticed less chicken and more veggies.  So it's getting iffy.  I think the last order was more zucchini and garlic than it was chicken.   

Other great dishes are the spicy chicken with fresh basil, sweet and sour shrimp, and twice cooked pork.

Service is fast and gruff, but not rude by any means.
author: Bobby L.

description:
Warning - they don't have a website and all prices online are 3 years old.

I ordered for pickup and thought the amount charged on my card (with no itemized receipt) seemed high. Sure enough, after checking the menu online, I had been charged about 20% higher. The Spicy Tangy Chicken at $8.95 on Yelp is actually $10.55 and the white rice at $1.50 on Yelp is actually $1.95.

I called to understand further, and the woman on the phone said that they don't update the online menu prices and that if I wanted I could get a paper menu in person... in 2016. She also said that most of their customers are return customers so they would know the prices, so I pointed out that they are then hurting their NEW customers. 

She said she just works here, so I asked if I could speak to the manager then, and she hung up. That's why I am here. The Spicy Tangy Chicken tastes fine although it is full of some sandy black flakes that really keep you on your toes.
author: Andrew W.

description: Food is great; however, it is definitely the worst costumer service in San Francisco! Employees are extremely rude and I guess owners don't mind it!
author: C M.

description:
The food is delicious! I can appreciate their huge portions. 

I hate dining in because these people are rude. I never get a smile, and when I paid for my food earlier today the man took my money and sat my food down on the counter and walked off instead of handing it to me. It's the little things people!!! And why is my total for the same thing I order always different?
author: Shannon P.

description:
This place is highly overrated. I have eaten here a few times only because my boss likes to go here, and I have tried many different items trying to find something that I like. Unfortunately I have yet to find a dish that was worth the price. 

The restaurant itself is not bad looking. Nice decor. But there is never any parking here. And don't get me started on the customer service. It is the worst out of any restaurant that I have ever gone to. Sometimes you find a bad waiter at a restaurant but this is not the case. All the workers here are extremely rude. Even when I call to place an order for pick up for my boss, they never say thank you, don't wait to see if you are finished with your order, and just hang up on you.

If it weren't for my boss who for some reason thinks this is the only Chinese restaurant in the city, ( she is a 92 year old lady ) I would never come back to this place.
author: Eddie E.

description: Casual, family orientated restaurant that offers delicious Chines cuisine.  A group of my friends and I went here last night and everyone just raved about the food. We ordered a lot, but the Mango Beef, Walnut Prawns, Vegetarian Chow Moon were the real standouts. Service was great. I haven't been to Eliza's for a few years, and the food is just as good (if not better as how I remember it).  I will say that the entrees were a bit salty and greasy, and does compel one to consume large amounts of water (probably not the healthiest of restaurants). The decor in the restaurant is also slightly tacky, but the quality of the food outweighs all of this. I highly recommend this restaurant and cant wait come back again soon!
author: Matt L.

description: I've been going to Eliza's at every one of its locations since 1988 and I've never had a disappointing meal. My faves are vegetarian chow mein, garlic eggplant and mu shu pork but in all honesty, every dish is delicious. It's my favorite restaurant!
author: Don R.

description: Been searching for a Hot and Sour soup in SF that is as good as my favorite Chinese restaurant back home, and Eliza's Hot and Sour is delicious!! Can't stop thinking about it. Saw they're on door dash, and I've been thinking about finally giving in and having some delivered to me!
author: Tony G.

description: Unless you're the type of person who goes to a restaurant to admire its decor or the art that is displayed,  you probably won't be impressed by Eliza's.  Eliza's is a beautiful restaurant, no doubt, but you'd have to be a real glutton for punishment to endure the bad customer service and the mediocre, small-portioned and over-priced food.  I'm surprised that this restaurant is still in business.
author: Danielle O.

description:
My financial advisor lives in Pac Heights and hails Eliza's as her go-to Chinese restaurant so naturally, the first time I was asked to housesit for a week, had to try it out. If you dine in, you'll be seated quickly. Although it's not the highest quality of service by the staff, there's nothing notably wrong with the service. If you take out, your order is ready under 30 minutes most of the time. 

Dishes worth mentioning: Eliza's spicy chicken (extra spicy), potstickers, sizzling rice soup, won ton soup and string beans w/ pork. 

A star off for the lack of delivery and lack of parking.
author: Ashley Nicole C.

description:
Wow (and not in a good way)! Extremely unimpressed with the food. Maybe my expectations were a bit higher based on some of the reviews, but the food and service were below par. We ordered the eggplant appetizer, Mongolian beef, and mu shu pork. 

Eggplant - horrible. It's basically one small Chinese eggplant split into 3 pieces with sprinkled minced garlic. 

Mu shu - this was the better if the 3 dishes. Good portions and tasty. 

Mongolian beef - horrible. No more words needed. The worst part, they lay the beef on a bed of "popped" rice to make the portions look more substantial. Do they think we're that naive???

One and done with Eliza's! So many other places with better food and service.
author: J J.

description:
Very disappointing. 

The food is full of oil and not testy at all. 
We ordered 5 main courses soup and appetaizers.... Nothing was testy. 

Also the service was bad, I felt like they doing me a favor serving me .

I use to have good memory from this restaurant more than 6 years ago... Not anymore!!! 
I'm not going back there, that's for sure!!!
author: Orly L.

description:
Eliza is in my threesome.

Everytime I'm in San Francisco, I have a favorite threesome hookup: Eric, Alice and Eliza.

Get your mind out of the gutter folks, I'm talking about Chinese food, and Eric's, Alice's and Elza's are three of my favorite San Francisco lunch spots.  

Eliza's is a great spot.  Easy atmosphere, fancy tablecloth casual, good food, and even better prices, this is an easy, fun trio.  At Eliza's, my favorites include the veggie Kung Pao with tofu (trust me on this!) , the simple and subtle prawns with lotus root and the sunflower chicken.  This is no Henry's Hunan.  The flavors are subtle, veggie forward.

Eliza's is phenomenal for lunch.  Fresh, delicious, really tasty, and light --lots of vegetables and great tastes.  Free jasmine tea.
author: Rachel H.

description: Delicious food but actually the worst service EVER. They are rude and inattentive. Asked for sweet and sour sauce and the waitress looked at me and walked away. This is not a one time event. Every time I am there they are consistently pompous and unpleasant.
author: Minna F.

description:
Eliza's is my favorite Chinese restaurant of all time.  Ingredients are fresh, portions are 'yuuuuge' and staff is courteous and accommodating.  

Every dish I've ever ordered has exceeded expectations (which never happens) and this is especially true for the wonton soup.  Best I've ever had.

I'm sure I'll be there again within the week.
author: Gregg D.

description: I love this place, BUT the only delivery is through doordash, which has disappointed. Please accept pick ups/deliveries through other apps!
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Eliza's has good vegetarian options, which I appreciate because it's hard to find decent Chinese restaurants that has dishes other than green beans.  I got the vegetarian mu-shu.  I definitely could've shared it with another person, but I wanted it all to myself.

I would definitely take my vegetarian friends here since there a lot of options that aren't compromised of mostly tofu.
author: Vira P.

description:
This is my favorite Chinese food in the city. Not because it's the overall SF champion (although it could compete for the city championship) but because I've been getting it 1x month for the past 10 years and it has NEVER failed.

Elizas produces arguably the best pot sticker in SF. Super meaty and just pops with juice and flavor. I'd also recommend the fried rice, Eliza's spicy chicken, hoisen green bean, moo shoo pork, and mango beef. The hot n sour soup never fails and the yellow chicken curry is delicious.

The problem is they don't deliver but I cannot dock them a star based on that. It's just a minor inconvenience as that I would order them 4x if they did.

They are however located close to a couple of bars so it's nice to grab a few beers watching a Giants game, call it in, and pick it up after 2 beers.

If you haven't tried Eliza's, make sure you do, it will not fail.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Beautiful location I must rave! We sat in the back surrounded by glass bamboo above! 

We had the lunch special, price was super affordable and good. I will eat lunch here again.
author: Diana K.

description: Eliza's used to be my favorite Chinese restaurant 5 years ago because I loved the food, while tolerating the horrendous customer service. The food quality has declined and the customer service is borderline unbearable. I honestly can't wait for this restaurant to shut down... and be replaced by a top notch establishment like Patisserie B or Tataki. Can someone please start a petition to evict Eliza's from our neighborhood?
author: Chris D.

description:
alright i have to keep it real... the service is kind of short... the food (it hurts to say this only because I didn't give in till now), but the food is one of the best chinese i"ve ever had... if u know any better please let me know...

I like the spring rolls, won tons, brown rice, mongolian beef, spicy chicken, or kung poa
author: Nolan M.

description:
If you're looking for a great Chinese restaurant with a side order of attitude, then Eliza's is your place. It's almost like something out of a Seinfeld episode. The food is good enough that you're willing to overlook the unfriendly staff. Just don't go in expecting servers with a smile or a thank you on your way out. It's not that kind of place.

That being said, Eliza's certainly serves some of the tastiest (and cleanest) Hunan & Mandarin food in town. I've been here on multiple occasions and tried numerous dishes, and I've never been disappointed. 

I'd certainly recommend their pot stickers ($4.95). Although there are only 4 per order, they're rather large dumplings. But if you're splitting dinner with friends, I'd recommend getting two orders.  Other menu highlights include their Drums of Heaven (think Chinese version of fried chicken), Mu-Shu Pork, Spicy Tangy Chicken, and Asparagus Salmon. I'm also a fan of their Chicken Chow Mein and Eliza's Fried Rice.

All their dishes are never too greasy, which is a common complaint of most Chinese restaurants. And for you health-conscious diners out there, you can order brown rice with your meal instead of the steamed white rice. 

The place is nice enough, I guess. Though the pastel interior reminds me more of a day spa than a restaurant. Personally, I prefer picking up food to go rather than eating at Eliza's. Though the last time I was there, I did see John C. Riley (from Step Brothers) dining in the joint - and that's kind of awesome.

Important to note - Eliza's closes early (9pm sharp). So be sure to place your order in time.
author: Kevin B.

description: My son loves their chicken chow mein, my wife loves their mango beef and I'm a sucker for their potstickers... It can get crowded so try to hit it at an off time.
author: Delta M.

description: Good was good.  Super fresh.  I had the spicy basil chicken for lunch.  The lunch specials are cheap and are good sized portions. Would visit this location again.
author: Brandi M.

description: Oh my God!  The staff here is so dam rude!! I will not be coming back here any time soon!!!
author: Precise L.

description: I must confess. The lunch menu portions leave me hungry.  I'm not a big guy and still if I dabble with the specials I feel like I just had an appetizer. So I do the sensible thing and order from the "regular" menu. For $10 (pre tax and tip) I chow down on some delicious food and walk out happy. What else can you possibly want from a little place that makes no claims to groundbreaking technique and has zero pretension? It's clean. It's tasty. It's really affordable. And the chicken or pork with long bean (and the hint of smoke that lingers on) is killer. I don't care if the wait staff aren't big on smiling. That's not why I'm here.
author: Jahan T.

description: We went there for weekday lunch. The meals were good and the soup was savory. Service was helpful. The decor was stylish.
author: Jim R.

description: We decided we wanted Chinese food for lunch and popped in after reviewing restaurants in the area. The food was superb and very fresh. We were greeted with a pot of tea too. Very clean too!
author: Brenda M.

description: Got the mango beef lunch special and a whole order of potstickers for 15 bucks. Mango beef was really good and got a decent amount of food for the price. Came with rice. The potstickers are pretty good, not the best but still tasty. Would definitely come back since I live nearby!
author: Michael V.

description: We were recommended to try this restaurant by a local. She advised us not to eat anything from Chinatown because they have a lot of problems with rats and unless you ordered in Chinese you never know what you were going to get. This place is in a good neighborhood and appeared to be very clean on the outside. On the inside is also clean and newer. It was very hard trying to order, the service did not speak English very well but we ordered the sizzling rice soup and it was fabulous. We ordered the chop Suey and it was very different than what we were used to. We also ordered a combination seafood plate which we did not like very well. Ending with the eggplant plate which tasted pretty good but again but very different than what we were used to. Overall the restaurant was clean but the service needs to be worked on a bit.
author: Chris K.

description:
As my friend's fav restaurant in lower Pac Heights, I was excited to try a Chinese restaurant off the beaten path. The ambiance is clean with modern decor. The lighting, on the other hand, could use a bit of improvement. Side note: Restaurants with poor choice in lighting really bother me, because lighting is one of of the main things that can make or break ambiance. 

We pretty much ordered the entire vegetarian menu (or what seemed like it) in order to sample a variety of things:

- vegetable mu shu: I had never before had this Chinese dish, but it was very interesting! Basically a do-it-yourself Asian fajita, the first was assembled tableside by the server, and then you proceed to assemble the remainder as you eat. Very tasty!

- vegetable chow mein: Served in a gigantic pot, this chow mein was loaded (loaded!) with fresh veggies! The proportion of veggies to noodles was excellent -- no skimping here! Just enough soy flavor, and not super oily.

- szechuan broccoli: Probably the blandest of all dishes. While the broccoli was steamed and tossed in a spicy pepper sauce, the heat didn't translate well, so I didn't get the szechuan vibe. Just okay, but skippable.

- spicy eggplant: Oh, dear. So obsessed with eggplant! Once again, melt-in-your-mouth pieces of eggplant that were an edible size and tossed with fragrant basil. Probably the dish that was most oily, but not overpowering enough to take away from the deliciousness!

- vegetarian kung pao with tofu: I have seriously never seen tofu so well-cooked in an Asian restaurant! Mucho props for the mini pieces of browned tofu tossed with typical kung pao sauce and veggies. An excellent take on your traditional kung pao chicken, and I didn't even miss the chicken!
author: Mansi A.

description:
I was excited to try this place based on the busy crowd 
(and line out the door for take out!), but we were extremely disappointed. In a city known for its Chinese cuisine, this place just doesn't cut it. Food was bland and lunch portions were small and mostly filled with white rice. I wish there was another option in the area, but unfortunately we won't be going back here.
author: Lauren K.

description:
I, too, have to agree with the others who wrote about the poor customer service. We rushed our other appointments to have lunch at Eliza's today. We drove around looking for street parking, found a spot, paid for parking, arrived just before 2:30pm and was told the kitchen was closed. The posted closing time is 3pm which I checked before we left. Also, my guest was leaving town, so we could not return for dinner.  I mentioned this to the manager who did not care. I cannot imagine running a business treating customers this way.

And please let me know the good places to eat Chinese food in the Richmond!
author: pat t.

description: best mandarin food in the city but worst customer service. take out is a must, I haven't gone in and sat down in over a decade. Eliza's spicy chicken, house chow mein and crab meat Rangoon are the best items on the menu.
author: Emma S.

description: I continue to love this place.  Invariably get one of the specials at lunch. All lunches come with a cup of soup, tea and a fortune cookie.  I have hit the trifecta when I come in and they have my fried eggplant with shrimp, brown rice and hot and sour soup.  Richard knows it is my favorite.  Grandson always gets house special duck. Veggies are nice and crunchy and plates are attractively presented with orange quarters (which I eat) for decoration.  They do not take American express.  We are part-timers on a limited budget and Eliza's gives us a wonderful meal for a very reasonable price.  The only thing bad about the place is that I am no longer satisfied with similar food back in Ohio.  While the menu will not overwhelm you with way too many choices, you will have a hard time making a decision because everything sounds good.  Just please, when I am in town, do not eat the last of the special eggplant with prawns!
author: Vickie B.

description: Good but not as good as I recall from 5+ years ago.  Lunch is a value meal.  Service ranged from perfunctory to grudging (my request for extra napkins yielded just one tissue thin small piece).
author: Peter L.

description:
I used to be a big fan of lunch at Eliza's on Potrero Hill, but California St?
Never again.
Take out order was minuscule, all except for the lunch special, 90% of which consisted of steamed rice.
Dude, seriously?!
Perhaps the Pacific Heights housewives prefer it this way so that they can split an order with one of their fit-bitted, cross-fitted pals?
Worst of all is the attitude...horrid.
It's as if they are doing you some sort of favor by accepting your hard earned dollars.
The one on Pot Hill closed unfortunately, this one is unfortunately still open.
Beware.
author: surf g.

description: Just gave Eliza's another try using take out. This is no exaggeration: the Mongolian Beef had more than HALF the carton filled with rice noodle FILLER (I call them "packing peanuts"). So, we payed 10 dollars for half a carton of mongolian beef. The sesame chicken was easily half a carton filled with these julienne-sliced carrots and onions, with the chicken on top. I will just warn you that with take out they are measuring their pennies by putting crap at the bottom of every dish to minimize how much meat they give you. If you want delicious food and a decent value, try New Country Sky or Tai Chi restaurant--both in the same neighborhood.
author: Mark D.

description: Haven't been here in over a year..And still the same!!  They are RUDE AF! They need to look into hiring here!
author: Charm T.

description: The food is so delicious. The service is very unfriendly.  They need to make eye contact with customers and seem somewhat happy that we are there spending our hard earned money.
author: Carolyn Y.

description:
Went here for dinner with some friends for a birthday dinner. I ordered the crispy peking duck as everyone ordered their own choices: crab rangoon for appetizers, mango chicken, spicy prawns and beef with broccoli. 

In the company of great friends, the dinner was good, however I'd had better.
author: Mika D.

description: Conveniently located by my apartment. Friendly staff and awesome food. They even remember my order!
author: Kevin D.

description:
Called at about 1:20pm this afternoon to place an order for pickup this evening at 5pm for a board meeting. They wouldn't take my order and said very rudely "We are busy. Call back at 2:30 to place order." If I could give them no stars, I would.

No thank you. Goodbye.
author: Jolly S.

description: I love this place!!! Food is pretty awesome, service is phenomenal, and the decor is one of a kind and amazing!
author: Geoffrey M.

description: Food is amazing! Service is pretty good. and Fast take-out!
author: Matilde M.

description: Lived in SF all my life and have eaten a lot of Chinese, both in restaurants and home cooking. This place is not up to par. The pork chow mein had a very weird tasting brown sauce, not what chow mein should taste like. And the sweet and sour sauce had a grainy consistency while I could taste the oil in the spring rolls more than the actual spring roll. Not worth the price.
author: So P.

description: Came here for dinner. I ordered the sesame chicken. It was ok. I like the rice soup a lot. This is not the best chinese restaurant in San Francisco. It is ok.
author: Isaac H.

description: Absolutely delicious!!!! Food is amazing and service is efficient and quick! Food came out very hot and fresh! Definitely try the chicken chow mein and the Mongolian beef! Really nice and clean restaurant, not dirty and dark like most Chinese food places! Five stars I will for sure be back!
author: Kayla A.

description: Always tasty at a great price. House duck special is my go to.   Funky decor to boot!
author: Chris B.

description: It was really sucks.The worst Chinese I've ever had.I ordered lemon chicken,wonton and Mapo Tofu.Can u believe that they just put the sweet sour sauce on the fried chicken and call it lemon chicken?And the wonton was undercooked.Never come again!
author: Keen G.

description:
Very Good Chinese Fusion Food

LUNCH: A Great Value!

I used to love the Hayes Valley location when it was there. (How long ago is that?)
author: BigJohnS F.

description: This was my first time here and I had been told the food was good, but it was fantastic!  The Prawns and Portabello mushrooms was to die for, and the portion was generous.  We also had the chow fun, they allowed us to substitute chicken for the imitation crab.  The flavor was very good, although it could have used a few more noodles.  The food was delivered promptly and the service was great.  It's popular so expect a short wait if you arrive during high traffic hours...
author: Michelle L.

description: Unbelievably bad. The food is actually okay. I've really enjoyed their Mongolian Beef and Sweet and Sour Chicken. I have seen a hair or two in my food a few times though, so the kitchen staff needs to step up their cleanliness. The worst part of Eliza's is the management and service. I've seen some racist acts by management, refusing service to some people. Their expectation for tipping is unreal, in fact almost demanding large tips in order to receive service at all. I can't support this kind of behavior anymore in my neighborhood. I'm incredibly disappointed that a local establishment in the city of San Francisco would be so close-minded to some people. The way that they treat their guests is pathetic. I hope that you read this review and rethink supporting this establishment, because they and their food don't deserve your money.
author: Edward M.

description: My food had a finger nail in it. Also hairs everywhere. Service took over and hour. Manager was rude.
author: Leron B.

description:
When my parents were visiting, we followed Yelp's reviews to Eliza's, and were not disappointed! The food takes classic Chinese restaurant dishes and adds some different flavors and presentation, while still keeping the spirit of the dish. We pretty much licked the plates clean. 

Also, the restaurant's interior / decor is unexpected but interesting and well kept!  

The only reason they get 4 stars and not 5 is that the portions are small for the price. However, the quality and flavor of the food overrides that. We will definitely be coming back.
author: Convict T.

description: Ordered a carry out rice, soup, and basil chicken. Greasy food that lacks flavor. Enough said.
author: Kim K.

description:
I came here with a group of my friends. One of them had suggested this place since it was a place they enjoyed so much. 

I gotten the pot stickers which by the way were huge, and very tasty. 

I also ate the Kung pao chicken which was also yummy, I just wish it came with more food. That just me otherwise the food was very good . 

The service was also very great and we were seated fairly quickly.

I would differently return.
author: Veronica V.

description:
I have been dining here for over 10 years.
They never disappoint. Their food is delicate with subtle flavors. I rarely write reviews but after reading that the wait staff is rude. I have never experienced that. Could it possibly be the diner's fault?!
Some of my favorite dishes are the pot stickers, any soup, Mongolian beef (any beef dish is good), prawns with eggplant, chow mein. Huge fan - don't listen to the haters!!
author: s b.

description:
The service in this restaurant is cold and lifeless. Two friends went in the other night about 8pm. The host said the kitchen would be closing soon so we'd need to hurry up. This as a table of ten was being seated next to us. The food was decent. The candied walnuts and shrimp slathered in mayo was killer. Very tasty. 

While the table of ten was finishing their meal, the host placed the check on our table. Two minutes later he walked by and tapped  his finger on the check, essentially saying "pay up boys." If it was a pickled female bartender it would have been charming. The food here is good, not great, and the service has the warmth of an interoffice envelope.
author: Greg D.

description:
Reasonable prices, but I'm always a little "iffy." I think they round-up and, when you question it, they just say "Oh, that's the tax..."

Anyways, the food is good. The prices are good. The atmosphere is good. It's all "good."

You'll definitely leave feeling satisfied and well fed.
author: Gabriela K.

description:
Craving C-Food? Stuck in an area in between Laurel Heights and Pacific Heights?
Can't get to Richmond or Sunset? Then you probably "sol" like I was today...
I had the hunan lamb, and it was just plain okay. Nothing special or stellar. Somewhat spicy...kinda greasy. Make the haul to Sichuan Home on Geary, if you want to taste a good lamb dish
author: Derek N.

description:
As a local, this is definitely going to be a place I hit up a lot. Lunch special is ridiculously cheap, which includes entree and soup. (min $6.20 for an entree but nothing really goes over $7). My lunch came out to roughly $9.00 after tax and tip.

They give you a healthy portion of whatever you order. I'm not feeling stuffed by any means, but I'm not exactly starved for $6 worth of food either.

Wait staff is a bit quiet, but friendly if you try to engage them. They seem pretty popular in the area and recognize customers.

Food is definitely really heavily spiced (hot and otherwise) and salted / sauced up pretty heavily, but I don' t necessarily go out to eat Chinese expecting anything different. Definitely a 4 star in the grand scheme of things, but 5 star for the price. So cheap!

Their soups are delicious by the way (try their hot & sour soup)! Great place to stop in for a quick lunch or get take out.
author: Skippy T.

description: I got the Hunan fish, take-out for lunch. I was slightly confused if it was slightly breaded or not because it was kind of chewy, but when I bit into it, I did not see a lot of breading and actually a great ratio of fish. After talking about a coworker who got the same dish, we think it was breaded, but the sauce made the exterior chewy. Having cut oranges in the same container as the entree was a little weird. If I eat here again, I would dine-in and order something different.
author: Christine P.

description:
I love this place. Solid, consistent family establishment. 

My favorite apps are the drums of heaven and the crab rangoon (shocking! I usually hate these from other Chinese spots). For entrees, I love the Mongolian beef and Eliza's spicy chicken (which is actually pretty mild, so go extra spicy if you want any heat.)

The decor in the restaurant is super interesting and I'm still noticing new things after ~10 visits.
author: Blaine C.

description: I dig this place. The vegetarian mushu and the potstickers were solid. I've been looking for a good Chinese restaurant so I'm glad to have found this spot
author: Alec H.

description:
Very good, somewhat Americanized version, Chinese food. The restaurant is actually pretty small with a poor , but pretty , layout.  If the place is busy the front waiting area makes you feel like you are in  a cattle car...but it is a popular place for a reason.

The pancake appetizer was excellent with the peanut sauce, the crispy spring roll was also very good..not greasy, the pot stickers also good.

They had Peking duck, which was a special that night, was sooo good..not greasy, plenty of meat...really tasty!  The mao po tofu was good...although could have been spicer with more peppers. Sesame chicken was so so, The fried rice is very good but their chow mein really sucks in my opinion. Walnut shrimp so so but the shrimp with basil was awesome.

Service, which many complain about, I thought was good....the family that runs the place really went out of their way to make everything run smoothly...even though it was a busy night and we had a big party.

If you are in this neighborhood check it out.
author: David G.

description:
I've always wondered how this restaurant was and after eating there tonight, it is on my go-to list for Chinese food. The decor is nice, it is clean and they have highchairs and are baby friendly. 

The sunflower chicken dish was very tasty and love the endive element. The string beams with bean curd was yummy. Decent alcohol list and reasonable prices.
author: Natalie S.

description: WORST DINING EXPERIENCE I'VE EVER HAD. The service there was incredibly slow; it took over an hour for us to get our chow mein and fried rice, after politely reminding them twice. Then when we received our food it was cold. The service was also very rude; one of the servers ignored me. Also they are very overpriced for the quality of their food, for example, $10 for fried rice that is barely big enough to feed 1 person. I will NEVER be going back.
author: Sierra A.

description:
Eliza's is that trendy modern-Chinese place that's somehow made it through the 90's and 00's and is still thriving today.  Probably the best to-go option for anyone living nearby (or those willing to deal with the nightmarish parking in the area).  

The decor is an interesting hodge-podge that I can only guess is supplemented anytime the owner looks at a blank area and decides to put something random in said area.  And yet it works. :)

The food is overall quite good, and pretty well priced.  But don't expect anything traditional/authentic here, the dishes have the same names, but Eliza's own unique preparations.  My favorites:

* Sizzling Rice soup - very light and delicate broth, I think I could make this into my entire meal

* Mongolian beef - deliciously seasoned meat with bits of crispy puffed rice - might sound weird, but it works, excellently

* Hunan salmon - again crispy puffed rice, combined with one of the few preparations of salmon in Chinese cuisine I've ever had that makes me want to come back for more.

* Sunflower chicken - another unusual preparation, and another very memorable dish.  nothing I can really compare it to, but it's a staple for our family

* Garlic eggplant - this is a "binary" dish - if you hate eggplant, this won't turn you into a fan.  but if you *like* eggplant, this is a must-have. a little crispy, with a great tangy sauce.

* DRUMS OF HEAVEN - so the drums are drumsticks, and as far as I can tell, they literally come from heaven. SO GOOD.

One last note - the place is definitely kid-friendly and a great option for the 6pm family rush hour, as it doesn't typically fill up until after 7.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Let's get down to business... 
To consume...
THE DUCK!

I came to Eliza's for one thing and ONE thing only: The Peking Duck!

My bff's family and fiance brought me here for dinner on a Friday night. Yes, we made reservations since it gets really crowded on the weekend. My party wasted no time once we sat down. We ordered two (yes, TWO!) Peking Ducks along with some dumplings and lo mein to accompany the quacksters. The food took a little long but everything came out piping hot and smelled delicious! Thanks to the Lazy Susan on the table, we were able to help ourselves and dig into the mass quantities of freshly made food before us repeatedly.

Verdict? Absolute perfection- the duck meat was so juicy and tender while the skin was crispy. The dumplings were top notch and I slurped those lo mein noodles so hard I think the next block over heard me. Ahhhh!!! I want some more please.

Wonderful meal and I know where to get my duck on next time I come out to SF.
author: Leslie D.

description: This place may not be super super authentic Chinese, but it'll suffice.  I absolutely loved their chow mein because they use the thicker, home made style noodles.  Those noodles are my favorite and takes me back to my childhood, when my dad was working at a noodle factory in Hawai'i.  It pretty much sealed the deal for a 4 star review.  My friend is a loyal customer of this place and raves about Eliza's spicy chicken.  Service wise, I'd say they're pretty stereotypical of Chinese restaurants.  The servers are no nonsense, get sh*t done kind of people.  You're here to eat, and then leave.
author: Diana A.

description:
Actually, the whole experience was anything but great.  From the rudeness of the help, to lukewarm food, to having to ask for more tea and water.  
It's OK that a place is cheap, but that does mean that rudeness and indifference is acceptable.  Everyone can rave about this place.  Not me!!  I will not return.
author: Linda M.

description:
You gotta try the crab ragoons here !!! Crab and cream cheese yummy !! and their potstickers are a good size and not too bad too 

All the food is served family style. We ordered the chicken fried rice.... it was pretty good a little salty for my own taste but good 
 
Also got the mushroom chicken now this had really great flavor 

And the bf got broccoli beef also really good nice crunchy broccoli and a good portion of meat 

But the was only server and he was running all over the place but still managed to get our last minute order of potstickers out before our entrée and working in the kitchen I know that can be hard to do so I gave it a 5 star 

I'm always around the area so I'll Definitely be coming back soon
author: christina a.

description: Not what it used to be. Was craving potstickers and this place used to hit the spot. Today, they were a soggy mess with flavorless meat. I guess they've changed chefs after all these years. Too bad. Will have to find a replacement Americanized Chinese restaurant.
author: Tina Z.

description:
Love this place. Great Chinese food. I have been going here for over 13 years and this place is still great and has not changed. 

Favorites include pot stickers, mu shu pork, hot and sour soup and Mongolian beef. On Friday and Saturdays they have the peeking duck which is delicious.
author: Alex T.

description:
It pains me to downgrade Eliza's to two stars!

Let me preface this by saying my updated review is based on in house service and not take out (as I had reviewed before) For take out- Eliza's food is 3-5 stars depending on what you order.

First of all... we have been coming to Eliza's (in the former locations near Van Ness, and in Portero Hill) for over 20 years. It is one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in all of SF.

Here's the problem, the service. News flash to Eliza's... people in SF have kids! We were seated with one our well behaved 6 year old. 

There were two other tables (elsewhere in the restaurant) with younger kids who were making a bit of noise and mess. Probably drove the waitstaff into super rude mode because we caught their wrath. 

Our waiter (a woman, working on evening of October 7) was downright mean. She made us (four adults) feel as if we were intruding and corrected our order when we wanted more rice. She basically refused to add it to our order. She was also very rude when collecting the dishes. I mean, seriously, it is an art form to be a rude table busser. That takes real talent! 

We had 5 people too and a $60+ check.

What made me really disappointed in the service, was the last straw... When we asked for a couple of additional fortune cookies, she rolled her eyes, made some nasty remark under her breath, and disappeared into the kitchen never to be seen again. 

I grabbed a second waiter for the cookies and he said "Yeah, yeah." Then yelled at my son for being near the walkway. He was just standing there minding his own business. No waiters were present and we were watching him. So again, BOTH waiters were incredibly rude!!!! 

The cookies never arrived. And we left feeling a bit betrayed by the restaurant where we had spent so much money in the past. 

Oh yeah, don't try Eric's or Alice's in SF either. Same family. Terrible food on those two.

Eliza's does have tasty food, well, two of our four dishes were good. But, DO NOT EAT THERE WITH KIDS!
author: Suzanne D.

description: I have been there for years but now the portions have shrunk so much you need expandable glasses to find meat on your plate.  The rice occupies most of the plate and leaves very little room for the veggies and tiny rare pieces of meat.  I won't go back, too bad because I used to like the place and I have been there many times.
author: Laurent G.

description: Good fresh tasting food with healthy interesting flavours. The house prawns were the best dish I encountered there and I am looking forward to exploring the rest of the menu.
author: Donald C.

description:
I don't know anything about chinese food, but thought it was decent food. 

I don't know that I have ever had AMAZING Chinese food, but I definitely enjoyed the decor. 

I wasn't paying attention to what was ordered or how much it cost but it was a nice gesture by our friends after we helped them move. 

I would definitely go back, hopefully with more of an appetite (I had lunch about two hours before dinner).



The level of english didn't seem to be that high.
author: Carlos A.

description:
The rudest service ever. 
Thursday night - we call ahead - letting them know we are coming. 
They are so rude. On the phone they tell us if you get here by 8:45, we'll serve you.
We get there at 8:45 on the dot. Rushed like heck to get there.
No one is up front.
They shoo us to the waiting area.
We are ignored until 8:50 and they say "too bad" - can't serve you - in a TOTALLY RUDE WAY!
We tried to make our point and got the big fat hand.
The manager is the rudest person in America.
NO WAY!
author: Andrew K.

description: Food here is alright, but customer service is terrible! My boyfriend loves this place and i wanted to take him there for his birthday, so I called and asked if they were open Memorial day and the guy on the other end of the phone gave a very annoyed "yes". Yeesh.
author: Janice L.

description: My favorite Chinese food in SF. Not saying I'm an asian food pro, but I live off Clement St. and come all the way here for my Chinese, so that must say at least something right?! Usually get take out but they have always been friendly to me either way. Love their Eliza's Spicy Chicken. Always huge and very fresh tasting.
author: Alexis T.

description:
It's really a 3.5, but I'll round up. The category for Eliza's really should be Chinese American, not Chinese. They're actually quite different. 

To start out the night, we ordered some Pork Mu Shu, which was yummy. The waiter wraps it up for you at your table using utensils (don't worry germaphobes). It's basically a mixture of pork, wood ear and other assorted vegetables tossed in some sort of light oil or sauce.

Honey Walnut Prawns were delicious. It was sweet, lightly covered in mayo and shell free. I don't usually eat the nuts in the dish, but the walnuts were really crunchy and addictive.

The Kung Pao Chicken didn't really make an impression on me. The chicken was cut into small bite-size chunks, coated in flour, deep fried to get a crispy crunch and then covered in a spicy Orange Chicken-like sauce.

The Mongolian Beef, a common staple of Chinese American restaurants, also impressed. The beef was tender. The sweet spicy brown sauce made the dish extra savory.

I still think Chinese American food is unnecessarily expensive. Chinese food should always be cheap cheap cheap!
author: Thy L.

description:
Dining room is, how you say, interesting.... kinda a "wanna be upscale".

Thought it was ok, with kind of the same response I had to the now closed Potrero Hill location:   http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=hEjhuWxQwDvP_B8yeCjDYg&q=eliza

Dinner was good I have to say, not great. Price was ok.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
I went here a few years ago and really liked it. The decor is pleasantly modern, everything looks clean and well maintained, and I found the food to be nothing like authentic, but at least well made with good ingredients.

I'm afraid they've gone way downhill, and I won't be back.

We had the Spicy Chicken with Basil, the Triple Mushroom with Snow Peas, and some steamed brown rice. 

The only thing which was ok was the rice. 

The Spicy Chicken with Basil was actually greasy red peppers with a bit of chicken and a few leaves of basil. It was not spicy and the chicken seemed to be whatever pieces were left over from cooking other dishes. 

We should have known better than to order mushrooms, because the Triple Mushroom with Snow Peas contained what appeared to be canned mushrooms. These taste nothing like mushrooms, and I was not able to eat them.

Times may be tough, and low prices are a good thing, unless it compromises the quality of the ingredients which a restaurant is using. I'd rather pay an extra $2 or $3 a dish and get better ingredients than to save them and end up with unappetizing food.
author: Jacob L.

description:
My friend and I ate here for lunch today. I ordered the chicken basil lunch special which was the first item on the list. It came with a soup and they gave us green tea also. My dish was a little less than just okay. It was 2/3 red bell peppers, which was not mentioned in the menu otherwise I would have changed my order, and 1/3 chicken cut pretty small. The chicken had fatty and gristly parts which was too bad since it was such a small portion of the meal already. The soup was gross, it had a really thick consistency with very little flavor. Service was slow - they took a while to bring the check and then change.

The good: The food was inexpensive, total we paid under $14 for food without ordering drinks. They have a brown rice option which is nice, and we were seated pretty quickly.

The bad: Food not great, soup all bad, service... meh. Nothing to write home about, and nothing to try twice.
author: Melissa B.

description: I want to report that Eliza's is no longer using soiled used table napkins to clean off tables. They either read my previous complaint, others complained or the health department got after them.  I'm happy that this problem was addressed.  I can happily also report that the food has been great and service excellent.  Serious waitstaff.....tending to tables wonderfully, not much conversation, just serious good service.I would highly recommend this restaurant for good and a little different Chinese Dishes.
author: Girly Foodie F.

description: Came here with my cousin who enjoys Eliza's as a local. Best Chinese food I have every had. The spicy eggplant was excellent. Mongolian beef superb. Prawns with walnuts and honey sauce - extraordinary. Great flavors. Fresh ingredients. Nice portions, too.
author: Dan Pucci P.

description:
Unless you are dining with screaming kids, there is no reason you would ever want to eat here. The decor is the weirdest thing you can find in SF, the staff does their best to make you feel you weren't there (and you'll be wishing the same after glancing down at the floor and seeing several days worth of old noodles piled up under the tables), and the food is average. 

If you have screaming kids and are looking for Chinese food in the area, it's perfect.
author: Carl A.

description:
This place is NOT as good as it use to be. Te food is bland and they give very small portions. I use to really like them. The family and I went last night and no one enjoyed the meal.
We ordered  5 different items. The only the item we liked was the pigstickers.

Szechuan eggplant w/prawns: had a nice flavor but the prawns were over cooked.

Lemon chicken: small portion and soggy

Hunan Salmon: mainly consisted of onions & bell peppers. Had to go on a scavenger hunt for the salmon and then it was dry.

Triple mushroom w/snow peas: no flavor at all.

Potstickers: tasty..

We will not be returning. We also got bad service. They never came back to check on us even though it wasn't busy..
author: Ayana K.

description:
We have been ordering the Chinese Chicken salad at Eliza's for awhile, but we have noticed lately their take out Chinese Chicken salad really disappoints. Mind you, at it's best it is spicier and more savory than Comforts of San Anselmo's Chicken Salad, but when it is at its best it is still paltry. Last night was even more so. There were hardly any greens and a disproportionate amount of spices (too much) to the meager amount of lettuce. 

Unlike Comforts, their chicken is questionable - it has been sauteed/fried and has been prepared in bits. Although, it is tasty, it is a bit of a mystery . Well, mystery solved; last night my husband and I literally had to spit out 8 to 10 pieces of this 'chicken' as it was pure gristle and bone! 

If you are going to make a smaller salad, keep up the quality! Now when we crave Chinese chicken salad we go to Comforts and pick it up when passing through Marin.
author: F C.

description:
Eliza's is very popular it's true. It is always busy and there is consistently a line of cars double parked picking up their to go orders.

Lunch specials are a pretty decent deal and I like that you can get brown rice as an option. Their chinese chicken salad while tasty is absolutely tiny. It is not a special, so it is full price therefor it should be an entree size salad... It is not.

Pot stickers, basil chicken, and mango beef are all quite good. 
The soups can be watery and underwhelming.

If you are craving Chinese it will do the trick but it is not a five star deal.
It isnt a great value. The portions are measly. The service is cranky and slow. It isn't that authentic or interesting and the presentation is not thoughtful. 
It is fresh and a little on the light side. California cuisine meets Chinese.
author: Melissa B.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE Eliza's!!! Excellent Chinese food with a creative twist. Fair prices, quick service in a clean and lovely environment. If you haven't tried Eliza's yet, what are you waiting for?
author: Roseann S.

description:
Came here with a friend today for lunch, and was a little apprehensive how authentic it would be considering, I ate plenty of Hunan food when I was in China.

All in all, it's decent Chinese food for lunch. $6.20 for some good chinese eggplant, soup, and rice? Yummy. Eggplant was properly cooked. My only complaint was that it wasn't spicy enough to be authentic, but I'll forgive them for that. Service was so-so, as the waiters seemed inattentive and a little standoffish, but I will take that for the decent quality of the meal.

And am I the only one who marvels at how much liquid they give you for lunch (soup, water, and tea)? My bladder was bursting at the end of the meal.
author: Tony H.

description: Eliza's makes decent food but their portion sizes are inconsistent, and some not worth price. The Mongolian Beef we got the other night might have been the biggest ripoff dish I ever seen from a Chinese restaurant -- they filled a small takeout container with airy dry noodles and put a spoonful of beef on the top -- weak!
